headline: Controversial Regulatory Standards Bill Passes Final Reading Amid Opposition Vows to Repeal
summary: Parliament saw the final passage of the highly contentious Regulatory Standards Bill, a cornerstone of the ACT party's agenda, which fundamentally alters how new laws are scrutinized. The government hailed it as a victory for accountability, while opposition parties condemned it as an undemocratic move and pledged its repeal. The day also featured heated exchanges over budget cuts to Fire and Emergency NZ, the government's redress plan for abuse survivors, and proposed changes to meat inspection services.

topicSummaries.topic: Regulatory Standards Bill Passes Final Reading, Sparking Fierce Debate
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: This new law changes how all future government regulations are created and assessed, requiring them to be measured against principles that prioritize individual liberty and property rights.
topicSummaries.content: The government passed the Regulatory Standards Bill into law, concluding a years-long campaign by the ACT Party. Minister for Regulation David Seymour argued the bill creates a more "civilised society" by forcing politicians to be transparent about the costs of regulation on individuals and their property, similar to how the Public Finance Act provides fiscal accountability. Opposition parties fiercely opposed the bill, with Labour's Dr Duncan Webb stating it "bakes in a libertarian set of values" and was opposed by over 99% of public submitters. The Green Party and Te Pāti Māori argued it prioritizes corporate interests and property over people, the environment, and Te Tiriti o Waitangi, with both Labour and the Greens vowing to repeal the legislation within 100 days of forming a new government.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon David Seymour (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: Where this bill leads us is a more respectful and more civilised society, one where if you want to benefit, if you want to pursue an objective that you think is worthy, and if you want to impose costs on other people... then as a start, you have to at least be open and honest about the fact that you're doing it.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Duncan Webb (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: What it amounts to is baking in a libertarian set of values into our lawmaking process, skewing the lawmaking process in a particular libertarian philosophical way. At root... it's about the protection of property rights, the protection of absolutely free use and exchange of property—in his words.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Defends Fire Service Budget Cuts Amid Public Safety Concerns
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: Proposed budget cuts of up to $70 million for Fire and Emergency New Zealand (FENZ) could impact staffing and equipment, raising questions about the service's ability to respond to emergencies.
topicSummaries.content: The Labour opposition challenged the government over proposed budget cuts of up to $70 million a year and the potential loss of 140 jobs at Fire and Emergency New Zealand. Deputy Leader Carmel Sepuloni questioned the timing of the cuts, referencing a recent major fire in Tongariro National Park and asking if public safety could be guaranteed. Acting Prime Minister David Seymour defended the government's position, stating FENZ had been asked to "manage within a budget" and that efficiency could be improved by "working smarter" rather than "throwing money at a problem." He argued that better asset management, which he claimed was neglected under the previous government, would ensure firefighters are well-resourced without impacting safety.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Will he guarantee that Fire and Emergency New Zealand's proposal to cut up to $70 million of spending a year—10 percent of their annual budget—will have no impact on the safety of New Zealanders; if not, why not?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon David Seymour (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: Yes, I most certainly do, and here's how—and it might enlighten members on the other side. Throwing money at a problem is not the same as solving it. It is possible to solve problems by working smarter, putting in place more competent people, and making better use of resources.

topicSummaries.topic: Minister Defends Government's Redress Plan for Abuse Survivors
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The government's response to the Royal Commission into Abuse in Care will determine how thousands of survivors receive compensation and support, with a key debate over whether to use existing systems or create a new one.
topicSummaries.content: The Green Party questioned the government's commitment to survivors of abuse in state and faith-based care, highlighting the Prime Minister's previous statements about implementing a new, independent redress system. Green MP Kahurangi Carter quoted survivors who feel the government has broken its promise by not establishing this new entity. Lead Coordination Minister Erica Stanford defended the government's approach, arguing that creating a new independent system would take "years and multiple millions" of dollars. She stated the government's priority was to provide "certainty and surety to survivors now" by improving and accelerating redress through existing agency processes, noting these steps would be necessary for any future independent system.

keyExchanges.speaker: Kahurangi Carter (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Is survivor Ihorangi Reweti-Peters correct when he said, "If this Government truly cared about survivors, they would have listened to survivors and the royal commission recommendations, and implemented a new, independent, single redress system."

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Erica Stanford (National)
keyExchanges.quote: We knew that implementing an independent redress entity would take years and multiple millions and millions and millions of dollars. We wanted to prioritise certainty and surety to survivors now, which is exactly what we've done.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Considers Meat Processor Self-Inspection, Sparking Trade Reputation Fears
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: Changes to how New Zealand meat is inspected could affect food safety standards and the country's multi-billion dollar export market, which relies on a global reputation for high-quality, safe products.
topicSummaries.content: The government is consulting on a proposal to allow meat processors to conduct their own inspections, a move from the current system primarily managed by state-owned enterprise AsureQuality. Labour's Rachel Brooking challenged the Acting Minister for Food Safety, Mark Patterson, on whether this would put New Zealand's "gold-standard reputation at risk." Mr. Patterson defended the consultation, stating the self-inspection model has been an option since 2013 and is already used for 17% of meat exports without issue. He assured the House that MPI was consulting with trading partners and would not implement any regime that would jeopardize the country's trade reputation.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Rachel Brooking (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Is he confident that our trade reputation won't be put at risk by meat processors doing their own inspections?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Mark Patterson (NZ First)
keyExchanges.quote: On behalf of the Minister, absolutely. MPI are consulting extensively with our overseas trading partners. There is no way we would put in place any regime that would put our gold-standard reputation at risk—so, no.

conclusion: The passage of the Regulatory Standards Bill marked a significant ideological victory for the government, while simultaneously drawing clear battle lines with opposition parties who have vowed to repeal it.
